title: Ryan Hunter-Reay
text:
Ryan Christopher Hunter-Reay (born December 17, 1980) is a professional American racing driver best known as a winner of both the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a> (<a href="2014%20Indianapolis%20500">2014</a>) and the <a href="IndyCar%20Series">IndyCar Series</a> championship in <a href="2012%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2012</a>. In each accomplishment, Hunter-Reay became the first <a href="Americans">American</a> to win since <a href="Sam%20Hornish%20Jr.">Sam Hornish Jr.</a> in <a href="2006%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2006</a>. Hunter-Reay also won in the defunct <a href="Champ%20Car">Champ Car World Series</a> twice and the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach</a>. In addition to his experience in Indy car racing, Hunter-Reay has competed in the <a href="Race%20of%20Champions">Race of Champions</a>, <a href="A1%20Grand%20Prix">A1 Grand Prix</a>, and various forms of sports car racing (the <a href="American%20Le%20Mans%20Series">American Le Mans Series</a>, the <a href="Rolex%20Sports%20Car%20Series">Rolex Grand-Am Sports Car Series</a> and the <a href="International%20Motor%20Sports%20Association">IMSA</a> <a href="United%20SportsCar%20Championship">Tudor United SportsCar Championship</a>).
Hunter-Reay last drove for <a href="Andretti%20Autosport">Andretti Autosport</a> in the IndyCar Series. When Hunter-Reay initially joined Andretti for <a href="2010%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2010</a>, he was only signed to drive for a partial season. Additional sponsorship was found and Hunter-Reay drove the entire season for Andretti. Hunter-Reay has since won both the Indianapolis 500 and the Verizon IndyCar Series championship.
Hunter-Reay most recently drove the number 28 car in the NTT IndyCar Series. The number is a show of support for the estimated 28 million people living with cancer worldwide. Hunter-Reay, who lost his mother to colon cancer in 2009, acts a spokesman on behalf of Racing for Cancer, an advocacy organization.
Career history.
Early career.
After winning six national karting championships in the <a href="World%20Karting%20Association">World Karting Association</a>, Hunter-Reay won a <a href="Skip%20Barber%20Karting%20Scholarship">Skip Barber Karting Scholarship</a> to race in Skip Barber Formula Dodge Series in <a href="1999%20Skip%20Barber%20National%20Championship%20season">1999</a>. Hunter-Reay won the series championship. Hunter-Reay then won a shootout against Formula Dodge drivers for the <a href="Skip%20Barber%20Big%20Scholarship">Skip Barber Big Scholarship</a> and its $250,000 prize. Hunter-Reay would use the scholarship money to compete in the <a href="Barber%20Pro%20Series">Barber Dodge Pro Series</a> in <a href="2000%20Barber%20Dodge%20Pro%20Series%20season">2000</a>.
Barber Dodge Pro Series.
Hunter-Reay began to compete in the <a href="Barber%20Pro%20Series">Barber Dodge Pro Series</a> in <a href="1998%20Barber%20Dodge%20Pro%20Series%20season">1998</a>. Hunter-Reay would drive the #28 <a href="Reynard%20Motorsports">Reynard 98E</a>-<a href="Dodge">Dodge V6</a> with no sponsorship. Hunter-Reay first competed in the race at <a href="Mid-Ohio%20Sports%20Car%20Course">Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course</a>. In the race Hunter-Reay started and finished in 23rd place after being involved in crash with <a href="John%20McCraig">John McCraig</a> on lap 22. Hunter-Reay returned to the series later in the season at the race at <a href="Homestead-Miami%20Speedway">Metro-Dade Homestead Motorsports Complex</a>. Hunter-Reay started in 21st place and finished in 22nd place after retiring due to damage to his car after 4 laps. Hunter-Reay scored no points towards the championship and finished 40th in the final point standings.
Hunter-Reay returned to the series in <a href="2000%20Barber%20Dodge%20Pro%20Series%20season">2000</a> to drive the #31 <a href="Reynard%20Motorsports">Reynard 98E</a>-<a href="Dodge">Dodge V6</a> with no sponsorship. At the season-opening race at <a href="Sebring%20International%20Raceway">Sebring International Raceway</a> Hunter-Reay started in 9th place and finished in 8th place. Hunter-Reay would qualify on the pole position at the race at <a href="Concord%20Pacific%20Place">Concord Pacific Place</a> and would finish in 8th place in the race. Hunter-Reay's best finish during the season was a 4th-place finish at the race at <a href="Lime%20Rock%20Park">Lime Rock Park</a>. Hunter-Reay would finish 5th in the final point standings with 104 points. Hunter-Reay would also win the series rookie of the year award and would receive sponsorship from the series for the following season as a result.
Hunter-Reay returned to the series in <a href="2001%20Barber%20Dodge%20Pro%20Series%20season">2001</a> to drive the #31 <a href="Barber%20Pro%20Series">Barber Dodge Pro Series Rookie of the Year</a>/<a href="Simpson%20Performance%20Products">Simpson Performance Products</a> <a href="Reynard%20Motorsports">Reynard 98E</a>-<a href="Dodge">Dodge V6</a>. Hunter-Reay would win his first race in the series at the third race of the season, at <a href="Lime%20Rock%20Park">Lime Rock Park</a>. In the race Hunter-Reay started in 2nd place and led for 21 of 30 laps and would set the fastest lap of the race. Hunter-Reay would win his second, and final, race in the series at <a href="Exhibition%20Place">Exhibition Place</a>. In the race Hunter-Reay only led the final six laps of the race after passing <a href="Matt%20Plumb">Matt Plumb</a>, who had qualified on the pole position, had the fastest lap of the race and every lap in the race up to that point. Hunter-Reay would also have a pair of 2nd-place finishes at the races at <a href="Sebring%20International%20Raceway">Sebring International Raceway</a> and <a href="Lime%20Rock%20Park">Lime Rock Park</a>. Hunter-Reay would finish 5th in the final point standings with 114 points.
Atlantic Championship.
Hunter-Reay began to compete in the <a href="Atlantic%20Championship">Toyota Atlantic Championship</a>, at the time the main development series for the <a href="Champ%20Car">FedEx CART Championship Series</a>, in <a href="2002%20Atlantic%20Championship%20season">2002</a>. Hunter-Reay would drive the #1 <a href="Medlock%20Ames%20Winery">Medlock Ames Winery</a>/<a href="U.S.%20Print">U.S. Print</a> <a href="Swift%20Engineering">Swift 014.a</a>-<a href="Toyota%20in%20motorsports">Toyota</a> <a href="Toyota%20A%20engine%234A-GE%20%2816-valve%29">4A-GE</a> for <a href="Hylton%20Motorsports%20%28Open%20wheel%20racing%20team%29">Hylton Motorsports</a>. Hunter-Reay would make his debut at <a href="Fundidora%20Park">Fundidora Park</a>. Hunter-Reay would start in 6th place and retire to finish in 23rd place. At the second race of the season, on the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Streets of Long Beach</a> Hunter-Reay started in 2nd place and finished in 18th place after having the fastest lap of the race. At the third race of the season, at the <a href="Milwaukee%20Mile">Milwaukee Mile</a>, Hunter-Reay qualified on the pole position, had the fastest lap of the race and led the most laps of the race. Hunter-Reay would retire from the race to finish in 19th place. At the fourth race of the season, at <a href="Mazda%20Raceway%20Laguna%20Seca">Laguna Seca Raceway</a>, Hunter-Reay qualified on the pole position, had the fastest lap of the race and led the most laps to get his first win in the series. Hunter-Reay would then finish in 4th place at the following race of the season, at <a href="Portland%20International%20Raceway">Portland International Raceway</a>. At the sixth race of the season, at <a href="Chicago%20Motor%20Speedway">Chicago Motor Speedway</a>, Hunter-Reay started in 6th place and led the most laps and had the fastest lap of the race to win his second race of the season. At the seventh race of the season, at <a href="Exhibition%20Place">Exhibition Place</a>, Hunter-Reay started in 7th place and finished in 4th place. Hunter-Reay would then get his third, and final, win of both the season and his Atlantics career at the eighth race of the season, at <a href="Cleveland%20Burke%20Lakefront%20Airport">Burke Lakefront Airport</a>, after leading the most laps. Hunter-Reay would then start 15th and finish 7th at the following race, at <a href="Circuit%20Trois-Rivi%C3%A8res">Circuit Trois-Rivières</a>. At the tenth race of the season, at <a href="Road%20America">Road America</a>, Hunter-Reay started 8th and retired from the race to finish in 24th place. Hunter-Reay then started 6th and finished 22nd at the following race, at <a href="Circuit%20Gilles%20Villeneuve">Circuit Gilles Villeneuve</a>. At the following race of the season, the season-ending race at the <a href="Pepsi%20Center">Pepsi Center</a>, Hunter-Reay retired from the race and finished in an unknown position. Hunter-Reay finished out the season ranked in 6th place in the final point standings with 102 points.
Indy car racing.
Champ Car World Series.
Hunter-Reay began to compete in the <a href="Champ%20Car">Champ Car World Series</a> in <a href="2003%20CART%20season">2003</a> to drive the #31 <a href="Stefan%20Johansson">American Spirit Team Johansson</a> <a href="Reynard%20Motorsports">Reynard 02i</a>-<a href="Ford%20Motor%20Company">Ford</a> <a href="Cosworth">Cosworth XFE</a> for <a href="Stefan%20Johansson">American Spirit Team Johansson</a>, a team owned by former <a href="Formula%20One">Formula One</a> and <a href="Champ%20Car">Champ Car World Series</a> driver <a href="Stefan%20Johansson">Stefan Johansson</a>. The previous year <a href="Reynard%20Motorsports">Reynard Motorsports</a> filed for bankruptcy and the Champ Car program became owned by <a href="Walker%20Racing">Walker Racing</a>. The chassis struggled to compete with the <a href="Lola%20Racing%20Cars">Lola B02/00</a>. The team also competed for the majority of the season without sponsorship. The only race that the team ran with sponsorship was the <a href="2003%20Gran%20Premio%20Telmex-Gigante">Gran Premio Telmex-Gigante</a> at <a href="Aut%C3%B3dromo%20Hermanos%20Rodr%C3%ADguez">Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez</a> where the car ran with sponsorship from <a href="Gonher%20de%20Mexico">Gonher de Mexico</a>. In the first twelve races of the season Hunter-Reay's best start was a seventh at the <a href="2003%20G.I.%20Joe%27s%20200">G.I. Joe's 200</a> at <a href="Portland%20International%20Raceway">Portland International Raceway</a> and a best finish of sixth at the <a href="2003%20Molson%20Indy%20Vancouver">Molson Indy Vancouver</a> at Concord Pacific Place. During this time Hunter-Reay was ranked 14th in points. At the thirteenth race of the season, the <a href="2003%20Champ%20Car%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Mid-Ohio">Champ Car Grand Prix of Mid-Ohio</a> at <a href="Mid-Ohio%20Sports%20Car%20Course">Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course</a> Hunter-Reay qualified in 2nd place and finished in 3rd place. Five races later at the season-ending <a href="2003%20Lexmark%20Indy%20300">Lexmark Indy 300</a> at the <a href="Surfers%20Paradise%20Street%20Circuit">Surfers Paradise Street Circuit</a> Hunter-Reay started from twelfth place and would make his first of three mandatory pit stops to get <a href="Racing%20slick">slick tires</a> as the track was changing from wet to dry in various parts of the track. Hunter-Reay would soon lead for 15 laps and would keep his car on the track while several other cars were crashing and/or spinning off of the track. Hunter-Reay would go on to win his first Champ Car race.
Hunter-Reay began to drive for <a href="HVM%20Racing">Herdez Competition</a> in <a href="2004%20Champ%20Car%20season">2004</a> in the #4 <a href="Herdez">Herdez</a> <a href="Lola%20Racing%20Cars">Lola B02/00</a>-<a href="Ford%20Motor%20Company">Ford</a> <a href="Cosworth">Cosworth XFE</a>. In the third race of the season, the <a href="2004%20Time%20Warner%20Cable%20Road%20Runner%20250">Time Warner Cable Road Runner 250</a> at the <a href="Milwaukee%20Mile">Milwaukee Mile</a>, Hunter-Reay would qualify on the pole position and lead for all 250 laps to get his second and final Champ Car win. Following the race Hunter-Reay was ranked third in points. Hunter-Reay's best finish in the remaining races was a 4th at the <a href="2004%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Road%20America">Grand Prix of Road America</a> at <a href="Road%20America">Road America</a>. In the race Hunter-Reay started second and made contact with former teammate <a href="Jimmy%20Vasser">Jimmy Vasser</a> on the first lap and dropped the two to the rear of the field. Hunter-Reay charged up through the field to get fourth place while Vasser finished eighth. Hunter-Reay would finish ninth in points (the only time Hunter-Reay finished in the top 10 in points in Champ Car) with 199 points.
In <a href="2005%20Champ%20Car%20season">2005</a> Hunter-Reay began to drive for <a href="Rocketsports%20Racing">Rocketsports Racing</a> in the #31 <a href="Lola%20Racing%20Cars">Lola B02/00</a>-<a href="Ford%20Motor%20Company">Ford</a> <a href="Cosworth">Cosworth XFE</a>. The car did not have consistent sponsorship and had to have sponsorship for various races from <a href="autobytel.com">autobytel.com</a>, <a href="Briggs%20%26amp%3B%20Stratton">Briggs & Stratton</a>, <a href="Cytomax">Cytomax</a> and <a href="Red%20Paw%20Systems">Red Paw Systems</a>. At the <a href="2005%20Centrix%20Financial%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Denver">Grand Prix of Denver</a> at the <a href="Pepsi%20Center">Pepsi Center</a> the car ran without sponsorship. Hunter-Reay's best finish during the season was a pair of 6th-place finishes at the <a href="2005%20Molson%20Indy%20Toronto">Molson Indy Toronto</a> at <a href="Exhibition%20Place">Exhibition Place</a> and at Denver. Following the <a href="2005%20Hurricane%20Relief%20400">Hurricane Relief 400</a> at <a href="Las%20Vegas%20Motor%20Speedway">Las Vegas Motor Speedway</a>, where Hunter-Reay started 16th and finished 10th, Hunter-Reay was replaced by <a href="Michael%20McDowell%20%28racing%20driver%29">Michael McDowell</a> for the final two races of the season. Hunter-Reay was 14th in points following the Las Vegas event and would drop to 15th in points after the last two races of the season with 110 points.
2007 - 2010.
Hunter-Reay began to drive for <a href="Rahal%20Letterman%20Lanigan%20Racing">Rahal Letterman Racing</a> in the No. 17 <a href="Honda">Honda</a> for the final six races of the season as a replacement for the released <a href="Jeff%20Simmons%20%28racing%20driver%29">Jeff Simmons</a>. Hunter-Reay made his series debut at the <a href="2007%20Honda%20200">Honda 200</a> at <a href="Mid-Ohio%20Sports%20Car%20Course">Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course</a>. In his debut Hunter-Reay started 10th and finished 7th. At the following race, the <a href="2007%20Firestone%20Indy%20400">Firestone Indy 400</a> at <a href="Michigan%20International%20Speedway">Michigan International Speedway</a>, Hunter-Reay started 12th in the race and had to make a pit stop to replace his damaged helmet. He would finish in 6th place and would be the last car on the lead lap. Hunter-Reay's best start of the season was a 5th at the <a href="2007%20Detroit%20Indy%20Grand%20Prix">Detroit Indy Grand Prix</a> at <a href="Belle%20Isle%20State%20Park%20%28Michigan%29">Belle Isle State Park</a>, where he finished 18th (last) due to clutch problems after 24 laps. Hunter-Reay would finish 7th after starting 12th at the season-ending <a href="2007%20Peak%20Antifreeze%20Indy%20300">Peak Antifreeze Indy 300</a> at <a href="Chicagoland%20Speedway">Chicagoland Speedway</a>. Despite only competing in six races, Hunter-Reay was able to finish 19th in points with 119 points and would win the <a href="IndyCar%20Series%23Seasons">series rookie of the year award</a>, setting the record for fewest starts in a season by a driver who won the award.
Hunter-Reay returned with <a href="Rahal%20Letterman%20Lanigan%20Racing">Rahal Letterman Racing</a> in <a href="2008%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2008</a>. At the season-opening <a href="2008%20Gainsco%20Auto%20Insurance%20Indy%20300">Gainsco Auto Insurance Indy 300</a> at <a href="Homestead-Miami%20Speedway">Homestead-Miami Speedway</a> Hunter-Reay started 9th and finished 7th. Hunter-Reay would then get another 7th at the <a href="2008%20Indy%20Japan%20300">Indy Japan 300</a> at <a href="Twin%20Ring%20Motegi">Twin Ring Motegi</a> after starting 10th. At the <a href="2008%20Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a> Hunter-Reay qualified in 20th place on the third qualifying day after crashing in turn 3 on Pole Day. However, he managed to finish the race without incident, finishing in 6th place and winning the <a href="Indianapolis%20500%20Rookie%20of%20the%20Year">race's rookie of the year award</a>. During the next four races Hunter-Reay's best finish was an 8th at the <a href="2008%20Iowa%20Corn%20Indy%20250">Iowa Corn Indy 250</a> at <a href="Iowa%20Speedway">Iowa Speedway</a>.
At the <a href="2008%20Camping%20World%20Indy%20Grand%20Prix%20at%20the%20Glen">Camping World Indy Grand Prix at the Glen</a> at <a href="Watkins%20Glen%20International">Watkins Glen International</a> Hunter-Reay started in 3rd place and was running in 4th place late in the race between <a href="Ryan%20Briscoe">Ryan Briscoe</a>, <a href="Scott%20Dixon">Scott Dixon</a> and <a href="Darren%20Manning">Darren Manning</a>. Briscoe and Dixon then made contact and dropped down the running order as a result. Manning took the lead only for Hunter-Reay to take it away on a lap 52 restart. Hunter-Reay would win his first IndyCar Series race and Rahal Letterman would win their first race in four years.
Hunter-Reay's best finish in the remaining races of 2008 was a 6th at the <a href="2008%20Detroit%20Indy%20Grand%20Prix">Detroit Indy Grand Prix</a> at <a href="Belle%20Isle%20State%20Park%20%28Michigan%29">Belle Isle State Park</a>. Hunter-Reay finished out the season ranked 8th in points with 360 points. Following the end of the season there was a non-points race, the <a href="2008%20Nikon%20Indy%20300">Nikon Indy 300</a> on the <a href="Surfers%20Paradise%20Street%20Circuit">Surfers Paradise Street Circuit</a>. In the race Hunter-Reay started 5th and finished 3rd.
At the end of the year <a href="American%20Ethanol">American Ethanol</a> withdrew their sponsorship due to financial problems and left Hunter-Reay without a team. Prior to the season Hunter-Reay tested a car for <a href="HVM%20Racing">HVM Racing</a>. Hunter-Reay was eventually offered a position at <a href="Vision%20Racing">Vision Racing</a> to drive the #21 <a href="Vision%20Racing">Vision Racing</a> <a href="Dallara">Dallara IR07</a>-<a href="Ilmor%20Engineering">Ilmor</a>-<a href="Honda%20Indy%20V8">Indy V8 HI7R</a>. The team had no sponsorship to start off the season, despite this Hunter-Reay managed to start 14th and finish 2nd at the season-opening <a href="2009%20Honda%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20St.%20Petersburg">Honda Grand Prix of St. Petersburg</a> on the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20St.%20Petersburg">Streets of St. Petersburg</a>. In the process Hunter-Reay gave Vision their best finish in an IndyCar Series race. Hunter-Reay's next best finish for the team came at the next race of the season, the <a href="2009%20Toyota%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach</a> on the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Streets of Long Beach</a> where Hunter-Reay started 12th and finished 11th. At the <a href="2009%20Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a> the team found sponsorship from <a href="Izod">Izod</a> and <a href="William%20Rast">William Rast</a>. Hunter-Reay struggled to qualify for the race and on Bump Day at 5:52 p.m. Hunter-Reay was bumped from the field by <a href="John%20Andretti">John Andretti</a>. Hunter-Reay was able to requalify, bumping <a href="Alex%20Tagliani">Alex Tagliani</a> by 0.0324 seconds. Hunter-Reay started 32nd after Tagliani replaced teammate <a href="Bruno%20Junqueira">Bruno Junqueira</a> in his qualified car. In the race Hunter-Reay spun in turn 4 on lap 20 and crashed, resulting in a 32nd-place finish. Following the <a href="2009%20Bombardier%20Learjet%20550">Bombardier Learjet 550</a> at <a href="Texas%20Motor%20Speedway">Texas Motor Speedway</a> Hunter-Reay and Vision parted ways. Hunter-Reay was then announced as the replacement for <a href="V%C3%ADtor%20Meira">Vítor Meira</a>, who was injured while racing at Indianapolis, in the #14 <a href="ABC%20Supply%20Company">ABC Supply Company</a> <a href="Dallara">Dallara IR07</a>-<a href="Ilmor%20Engineering">Ilmor</a>-<a href="Honda%20Indy%20V8">Indy V8 HI7R</a> for <a href="A.J.%20Foyt%20Enterprises">A.J. Foyt Enterprises</a>. In his debut for the team at the <a href="2009%20Iowa%20Corn%20Indy%20250">Iowa Corn Indy 250</a> at <a href="Iowa%20Speedway">Iowa Speedway</a> Hunter-Reay only completed 2 laps due to a crash. Hunter-Reay would only get two top 10s for Foyt with a 7th at the <a href="2009%20Honda%20Indy%20Toronto">Honda Indy Toronto</a> at <a href="Exhibition%20Place">Exhibition Place</a> and a 4th at the <a href="2009%20Honda%20200">Honda Indy 200</a> at <a href="Mid-Ohio%20Sports%20Car%20Course">Mid-Ohio Sports Car Course</a>. Hunter-Reay's only top 10 start of the season for either Vision or Foyt was a 7th at Mid-Ohio. Hunter-Reay would finish 15th in points with 298 points. Hunter-Reay was 10th in points following his split from Vision.
In <a href="2010%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2010</a> Hunter-Reay began to drive for <a href="Andretti%20Autosport">Andretti Autosport</a> in a part-time schedule that would consist of all races through the <a href="Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a>. Hunter-Reay would drive the #37 <a href="Izod">Izod</a> <a href="Dallara">Dallara IR07</a>-<a href="Ilmor%20Engineering">Ilmor</a>-<a href="Honda%20Indy%20V8">Indy V8 HI7R</a>. At the season-opening <a href="2010%20S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20Indy%20300">São Paulo Indy 300</a> on the <a href="S%C3%A3o%20Paulo%20Indy%20300">Streets of São Paulo</a> Hunter-Reay started 4th and would lead for 20 laps, only to be passed by <a href="Will%20Power">Will Power</a> on lap 58 of 61. Three races later at the <a href="2010%20Toyota%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach</a> on the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Streets of Long Beach</a> Hunter-Reay started 2nd, set the fastest race lap and led for 64 of 85 laps to win the race. Following the race Hunter-Reay was ranked 3rd in points. At the next race, the <a href="2010%20RoadRunner%20Turbo%20Indy%20300">RoadRunner Turbo Indy 300</a> at <a href="Kansas%20Speedway">Kansas Speedway</a> Hunter-Reay started 22nd and finished 5th. At the <a href="2010%20Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a> Hunter-Reay qualified in a disappointing 17th place. In the race Hunter-Reay was on his way to a top 10 finish when on lap 199 in turn 3 he ran out of fuel causing <a href="Mike%20Conway">Mike Conway</a> to drive over the left side of Hunter-Reay's car and flip into the catchfence. At the same time Hunter-Reay lost control and drove into the wall. Hunter-Reay would finish in 18th place. Following the race Hunter-Reay was 5th in points and was given additional races. The team would race with additional sponsorship from <a href="American%20Ethanol">Ethanol</a> at select races. Prior to the <a href="2010%20Camping%20World%20Grand%20Prix%20at%20The%20Glen">Camping World Grand Prix at The Glen</a> at <a href="Watkins%20Glen%20International">Watkins Glen International</a> Hunter-Reay was announced as a driver for all the remaining races. Hunter-Reay's best finish following Indianapolis was a 3rd at the <a href="2010%20Honda%20Indy%20Toronto">Honda Indy Toronto</a> at <a href="Exhibition%20Place">Exhibition Place</a>. Hunter-Reay would finish 7th in the final point standings with 445 points.
2011-2014.
In <a href="2011%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2011</a> Hunter-Reay returned with <a href="Andretti%20Autosport">Andretti Autosport</a> to drive the #28 <a href="DHL%20Express">DHL</a>/<a href="Sun%20Drop">Sun Drop</a> <a href="Dallara">Dallara IR07</a>-<a href="Ilmor%20Engineering">Ilmor</a>-<a href="Honda%20Indy%20V8">Indy V8 HI7R</a>. At the first two races of the season, the <a href="2011%20Honda%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20St.%20Petersburg">Honda Grand Prix of St. Petersburg</a> on the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20St.%20Petersburg">Streets of St. Petersburg</a> and the <a href="2011%20Indy%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Alabama">Honda Indy Grand Prix of Alabama</a> at <a href="Barber%20Motorsports%20Park">Barber Motorsports Park</a>. In these races Hunter-Reay finished 21st (retired due to handling) and 14th in the races. At the third race of the season, the <a href="2011%20Toyota%20Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">2011 Toyota Grand Prix of Long Beach</a> on the <a href="Grand%20Prix%20of%20Long%20Beach">Streets of Long Beach</a> Hunter-Reay started 2nd and led for 2 laps. In the race Hunter-Reay moved up through the field. After completing 168 laps Hunter-Reay had to retire from the race due to a damaged suspension and would finish in 21st place. Following the race Hunter-Reay became ineligible to win the championship due to points leader Power leading Hunter-Reay by 93 points (Power would get 10 points for failing to start the race while Hunter-Reay could get 100 points for winning the race, causing Power to win the championship by 3 points). 2015-2021.
Hunter-Reay struggled significantly following the 2014 season. Over a six-year window he only recorded five wins and no wins since winning in Sonoma in <a href="2018%20IndyCar%20Series">2018</a>, while Andretti Autosport as whole secured two Indianapolis 500 victories and younger drivers <a href="Alexander%20Rossi">Alexander Rossi</a> and <a href="Colton%20Herta">Colton Herta</a> emerged as the lead drivers for the team over the same span. On August 18, 2021, Hunter Reay announced he would be leaving Andretti Autosport and would be retiring from full time IndyCar competition, though he will to return for the Indianapolis 500 and other select events with a new team.

Hunter-Reay finished 33rd in the DP drivers championship. The #10 VelocityWW entry finished 2nd in the DP teams championship with 339 points.
IMSA Tudor United SportsCar Championship.
Hunter-Reay began to compete in the <a href="International%20Motor%20Sports%20Association">IMSA</a> <a href="United%20SportsCar%20Championship">Tudor United SportsCar Championship</a> after the <a href="American%20Le%20Mans%20Series">American Le Mans Series</a> and the <a href="Rolex%20Sports%20Car%20Series">Rolex Grand-Am Sports Car Series</a> merged in 2013. Hunter-Reay would drive for <a href="Street%20and%20Racing%20Technology">SRT Motorsports</a> in the #91 <a href="Street%20and%20Racing%20Technology">Street and Racing Technology</a> <a href="Dodge%20Viper">SRT Viper</a> GTS-R-<a href="Street%20and%20Racing%20Technology">SRT</a> 8.0 L V10 in the GTLM class. At the season-opening <a href="2014%2024%20Hours%20of%20Daytona">Rolex 24 at Daytona</a> Hunter-Reay co-drove with <a href="Dominik%20Farnbacher">Dominik Farnbacher</a> and <a href="Marc%20Goossens">Marc Goossens</a>. The car would qualify on the pole position in its class and in 24th place overall. The car would complete 675 laps to finish in 3rd place in its class and in 12th place in its class. Hunter-Reay then competed in the second race of the season, the <a href="2014%2012%20Hours%20of%20Sebring">12 Hours of Sebring</a>. Hunter-Reay drove the same car with the same co-drivers from Daytona. The car started in 10th place in its class and in 35th place overall. The car would complete 284 laps to finish in 7th place in its class and in 18th place overall. Hunter-Reay would compete in the season-ending <a href="2014%20Petit%20Le%20Mans">Petit Le Mans</a> in the same car with <a href="Kuno%20Wittmer">Kuno Wittmer</a> and Goosens. The car would start in 26th place and would finish in 11th place overall with 392 laps complete. The car would finish in 3rd place in its class. Hunter-Reay would finish in 19th place in the GTLM drivers championship with 87 points. The #91 SRT Motorsports entry would finish in 3rd place in the GTLM teams championship with 314 points.
Race of Champions.
Hunter-Reay was invited to compete in the <a href="Race%20of%20Champions">Race of Champions</a> in <a href="2012%20Race%20of%20Champions">2012</a>. Hunter-Reay was the only driver to compete to represent the <a href="IndyCar%20Series">IndyCar Series</a> and would be the first driver since <a href="Bertrand%20Baguette">Bertrand Baguette</a> in <a href="2010%20Race%20of%20Champions">2010</a> to represent the series. Hunter-Reay was part of the <a href="North%20America">Americas</a> team with <a href="Mexico">Mexican</a> driver <a href="Benito%20Guerra%2C%20Jr.">Benito Guerra, Jr.</a> In the Group A races of the Nations Cup Hunter-Reay would have 1 win and 2 losses while Guerra would have 2 wins and 1 loss. The team's first race was against the <a href="Race%20of%20Champions">All-Stars</a> team. In Hunter-Reay's first race he raced against <a href="Tom%20Kristensen%20%28racing%20driver%29">Tom Kristensen</a> and the two each raced in <a href="Volkswagen">Volkswagen</a> <a href="Volkswagen%20Scirocco">Sciroccos</a>. Kristensen would win the race with a time of 1 minute and 23.0759 seconds compared to Hunter-Reay's time of 1 minute and 24.5635 seconds. Guerra would win in his race against <a href="Jorge%20Lorenzo">Jorge Lorenzo</a>. The team's next race came against the <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> team. Hunter-Reay would compete against <a href="David%20Coulthard">David Coulthard</a> and the two each raced in <a href="KTM">KTM</a> <a href="KTM%20X-Bow">X-Bows</a>. Hunter-Reay would win the race with a time of 1 minute and 19.1336 seconds compared to Coulthard's time of 1 minute and 16.2360 seconds, which had 5 seconds added to it due Coulthard making a false start. Guerra lost in his race against <a href="Andy%20Priaulx">Andy Priaulx</a>. The team's third and final race in Group A was against the <a href="France">France</a> team. Hunter-Reay would race against <a href="Romain%20Grosjean">Romain Grosjean</a> and the two each raced in <a href="Audi">Audi</a> <a href="Audi%20R8">R8 LMSes</a>. Grosjean would beat Hunter-Reay in the race with a time of 1 minute and 16.5117 seconds compared to Hunter-Reay's time of 1 minute and 18.5096 seconds, which had 5 seconds added to it due to Hunter-Reay making a false start. Guerra would win in his race against <a href="S%C3%A9bastien%20Ogier">Sébastien Ogier</a>. The team would finish in 3rd place in the Group A results behind the France and All-Stars teams. The team would fail to qualify for the semifinals. In the Race of Champions races Hunter-Reay would compete in Group D. In Hunter-Reay's first race he competed against <a href="Kazuya%20Oshima">Kazuya Oshima</a> and the two each raced in <a href="KTM">KTM</a> <a href="KTM%20X-Bow">X-Bows</a>. In the race Hunter-Reay won with a time of 1 minute and 17.0206 seconds compared to Oshima's time of 1 minute and 22.5314 seconds, which had 5 seconds added to it due to Oshima making a false start. In Hunter-Reay's second race he competed against Grosjean and each raced in <a href="Race%20of%20Champions">ROC Cars</a>. In the race Grosjean won with a time of 1 minute and 19.3890 seconds compared to Hunter-Reay's time of 1 minute and 26.2154 seconds, which 5 seconds added to it due to Hunter-Reay making a false start. In Hunter-Reay's final race in Group D he competed against <a href="Michael%20Schumacher">Michael Schumacher</a> and each raced in <a href="NASCAR%20Whelen%20Euro%20Series">Euro Racecars</a>. In the race Schumacher won the race with a time of 1 minute and 17.8680 seconds compared to Hunter-Reay's time of 1 minute and 25.2427 seconds, which had 5 seconds added to it due to Hunter-Reay making a false start. Hunter-Reay would finish in 3rd place in the Group D standings with 1 win and 2 losses, finishing behind Schumacher and Grosjean. Hunter-Reay would fail to qualify for the quarterfinals.
Hunter-Reay would return to the races in <a href="2014%20Race%20of%20Champions">2014</a> and would be the only representative of the <a href="IndyCar%20Series">Verizon IndyCar Series</a>. In the team events <a href="Kurt%20Busch">Kurt Busch</a> would be Hunter-Reay's teammate. Busch had been Hunter-Reay's teammate at <a href="Andretti%20Autosport">Andretti Autosport</a> for the <a href="2014%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2014</a> 2014 Indianapolis 500.
Personal life.
Marriage.
Hunter-Reay is married to ex-<a href="Champ%20Car">Champ Car World Series</a> pit reporter, and off-road racing driver, <a href="Beccy%20Gordon">Beccy Gordon</a>, sister of former <a href="Champ%20Car">Champ Car World Series</a>, <a href="NASCAR">NASCAR</a> <a href="NASCAR%20Sprint%20Cup%20Series">Sprint Cup Series</a> and <a href="IndyCar%20Series">Verizon IndyCar Series</a> driver and <a href="Robby%20Gordon%20Motorsports">car owner</a> <a href="Robby%20Gordon">Robby Gordon</a>. Their son Ryden was born on December 28, 2012. They welcomed a second son Rocsen Indy Hunter-Reay in March 2015. Ryan and Beccy welcomed their third son Rhodes on September 14, 2016.
Number 28.
Since the <a href="2011%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2011 season</a> Hunter-Reay's car number has been 28. The number 28 is meant to represent the estimated 28 million people that live with <a href="cancer">cancer</a>. In 2009 Hunter-Reay's mother died of <a href="Large%20intestine">colon</a> <a href="cancer">cancer</a>. During the <a href="2013%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2013 season</a> Hunter-Reay, as the defending series champion, used number 1 as his car number. This would be the first time that a defending champion has used #1 in the <a href="IndyCar%20Series">Verizon IndyCar Series</a> since <a href="Scott%20Dixon">Scott Dixon</a> in <a href="2004%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2004</a> (although <a href="Michael%20Andretti">Michael Andretti</a> did use #1 in a one-off race during the <a href="2006%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">2006 season</a> at the <a href="2006%20Indianapolis%20500">Indianapolis 500</a> due to <a href="Andretti%20Autosport">the team</a> winning the championship <a href="2005%20IndyCar%20Series%20season">the previous season</a> with <a href="Dan%20Wheldon">Dan Wheldon</a>). During the 2013 season a small 28 was placed inside of the 1.
Other.
Hunter-Reay currently resides in <a href="Fort%20Lauderdale%2C%20Florida">Fort Lauderdale, Florida</a>. He <a href="fishing">fishes</a> in his spare time, stating "it's a great escape from anything". He owns a Yellowfin Yachts 42-foot yacht named "Inside Line" which he uses on his fishing trips.
